entities.name: Atlantis (Mythical City)
entities.definition: Lost city with 'arches, pillars, colonnades, not to mention vehicles and animals' that went under

evidence.quote: a whole city—arches, pillars, colonnades, not to mention vehicles and animals—had all one fine day gone under

entities.name: Our Old City
entities.definition: Personal lost place characterized by 'white pepper, white pudding' and intimate meetings

evidence.quote: I miss our old city — white pepper, white pudding, you and I meeting under fanlights and low skies to go home in it

entities.name: Speaker/Wondering Voice
entities.definition: Questioning consciousness that 'used to wonder' and moves from myth to personal experience

evidence.quote: How on earth did it happen, I used to wonder

entities.name: Old Fable-Makers
entities.definition: Ancient storytellers who 'searched hard for a word to convey that what is gone is gone forever'

evidence.quote: the old fable-makers searched hard for a word to convey that what is gone is gone forever and never found it

entities.name: Named Sorrow
entities.definition: Unnamed grief given identity as 'Atlantis' when no adequate word existed for permanent loss

evidence.quote: they gave their sorrow a name and drowned it

entities.name: Drowning/Submersion
entities.definition: Act of sinking beneath water that transforms cities and sorrows into unreachable depths

entities.name: Search for Words
entities.definition: Linguistic quest to find adequate expression for irreversible loss that ultimately fails

evidence.quote: searched hard for a word to convey that what is gone is gone forever and never found it

morphisms.statement: Speaker transforms from wondering about mythical city to recognizing symbolic function

evidence.quote: How on earth did it happen, I used to wonder... Maybe what really happened is this

morphisms.statement: Personal lost city parallels and explains the creation of Atlantis myth

evidence.quote: I miss our old city... Maybe what really happened is this: the old fable-makers searched hard for a word

morphisms.statement: Ancient storytellers initiated failed linguistic quest for expression of permanent loss

evidence.quote: the old fable-makers searched hard for a word to convey that what is gone is gone forever and never found it

morphisms.statement: Failure to find adequate word necessitated naming and drowning sorrow as Atlantis

evidence.quote: never found it. And so... they gave their sorrow a name and drowned it

morphisms.statement: Named sorrow undergoes same submersion process as mythical city

evidence.quote: they gave their sorrow a name and drowned it

olog.name: Atlantis as Symbolic Loss System
axioms: Personal loss mirrors mythical disappearance in scale and finality
Language inadequacy necessitates metaphorical substitution for grief
Geographic submersion parallels emotional burial of sorrow
Collective myths emerge from individual inability to name loss
Wonder transforms into recognition of symbolic function
rules: IF adequate words for loss cannot be found THEN metaphorical naming occurs
IF sorrow requires expression THEN geographical metaphors provide container
IF personal loss needs universality THEN mythical frameworks emerge
IF cities disappear completely THEN questioning consciousness awakens

evidence.quote: I miss our old city — white pepper, white pudding, you and I meeting under fanlights and low skies
searched hard for a word to convey that what is gone is gone forever and never found it
they gave their sorrow a name and drowned it
